Head 1201 -

    Mr Cheong Yuen Chee (Toa Payoh): Mr Speaker, Sir,

    I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for head 1201 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1001*. (*The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr P. Govindaswamy.)

    Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether he would consider setting up a recuperation centre for people who are recuperating from mental illness and who had been treated at Woodbridge Hospital. It is true that Woodbridge Hospital has excellent facilities for the treatment of mental patients. However, many mental patients who are considered fit are sent home to stay with their families. From the medical point of view, this may be desirable. But from the social point of view, this creates problems for the families of the mentally sick, especially those who stay in Housing Board flats. On account of the close proximity of the flats, a mental

Column: 935

patient who has been discharged from the hospital is easily identified by the residents and is shunned and ridiculed. Such attitudes not only affect the mental well-being of the patient but also affect the relationship between his family and his neighbours. As a result, tremendous strain is imposed on the patient's family. They are treated as social outcasts by their misfortune of having mentally ill persons staying with them. Families of such patients, and neighbours alike, request for transfers to other flats, in one instance, a patient pounded on the doors of neighbouring flats in the middle of the night. In another instance, a patient consistently abused and threatened her neighbours, although she turned out to be harmless. There are other instances, but it would take too long a time for me to elaborate.

    I must say, Mr Speaker, Sir, that the Woodbridge Hospital authorities have been very helpful when such cases are referred to them. The patients are readmitted but discharged again after a period of observation and treatment. The solution does not end there. What we need is a place, preferably outside the Hospital, where discharged patients can be taken care of or trained to do something useful, maybe on the lines of the Trafalgar Home.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, in addition to this amendment on Head 1201, I have another amendment* on Head 1202, Hospitals Division. Can I range over both amendments, Sir?

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, recently, while one criminal was under treatment in a hospital, he got the help of an accomplice and escaped. After this incident, I want to know what measures have been taken to tighten up security in the wards where prisoners are being treated?

    The doctors who work in the hospitals sometimes have to be on duty for 24

Column: 936

hours at one stretch. Although they are allowed time to sleep in special rooms, theoretically they are supposed to have some rest, but in practice it does not work that way.

    An hon. Member: Hear, hear!

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: A person whose sleep is interrupted every few hours is not going to be a person with good judgment in emergency cases. Are our citizens, who are sick in hospital, made to suffer at the hands of doctors, who have had insufficient rest? Surely it is inhuman to make a person work under such tiring circumstances. No wonder, despite all the incentives in pay and promotion prospects, there is a high rate of resignation among doctors.

    Sir, may I also ask the Minister why the Thomson Road General Hospital does not deal with compound fracture cases? Recently, a person in a chase after some boys, fractured an arm and was taken to the Thomson Road General Hospital. The authorities made the poor man wait for more than two hours I mean two hours - before advising him to go to the Outram Road General Hospital as there were no facilities available at that hospital. We cannot make boast of our hospital service if we have cases like this. I wonder how many citizens have been made to suffer unnecessarily by the authorities of this particular hospital. According to the numerous complaints in the newspapers, I guess there must have been many cases. Can the Minister do something about this matter and remedy the situation?

    Sir, I would like to know how long does the emergency ward in the Outram Road General Hospital take to deal with emergency cases. Recently there was an old lady suffering from a heart attack. She was taken to the hospital by an ambulance at 8 a.m, and was put in one corner unattended till 10 a.m. I wonder why the hospital authorities take such a long time to deal with emergency

Column: 937

cases. Either the doctors cannot cope with emergency cases or something is wrong with the section. Can the Minister do something to remedy the situation at the Emergency Ward? I have mentioned only one case, but I am sure there are many other similar cases which might have cost some lives as a result of such delays.

    Another point I would like to raise, Sir, is a complaint I received from a patient that some hospital nurses, who attend to patients, are unable to make out the prescriptions of medicines written in the case-history of patients which is kept beside the patient. The complaint was that a nurse, in going through a case-history, was heard to have told another nurse that she presumed the medicine should be this and that. This sort of presumption is not a playful matter because the medicine given to the patients could be the wrong one and might cause mishaps eventually. Can the Minister look into this complaint of "presumptions" by nurses and see that they do not discuss such matters in front of patients, which may cause worry to the patients who are on the sick bed.

    Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, we have just heard some complaints about the Ministry of Health as well as the medical practitioners. I do not pretend to answer for any of these. Sir, half a year ago during the debate on the President's Address in this House, I raised certain issues about health and hospitals. At this sitting of Parliament, allow me to bring to light again these problems facing the Ministry of Health and the good health of our citizens today and tomorrow.

    It is with pride, Sir, to note, if not with assurance, that the standard of health care and the facilities available in Singapore is today the best in Southeast Asia. The Minister for Health has recently announced plans for the construction of new hospitals in the years to come. This, I am sure will further boost the Republic as a health centre in this part of the world. Already an

Column: 938

increasing number of patients have come here from neighbouring countries to seek expert medical attention.

    Recently, in the salary revision exercise for senior Division I officers, additional incentives were given to consultant medical specialists to remain in service. This is a positive step to slow down the drain of the specialists into the more attractive and more lucrative private sector. However, salary and service conditions for the vast majority of institutional doctors, dentists, pharmacists, nurses and other ancillary staff, remain much the same. It seems imperative to me that corrective adjustments in terms of salary and service conditions must be made if we are to prevent the present trend, short of an exodus, of moving into the private sector. A hospital with top specialists but inadequately supported by junior specialists and doctors is no good hospital at all. In other words, it is like a military establishment with generals and no army. Perhaps, what is more disturbing is the shocking and escalating trend today for fewer and fewer students from our schools to enter the medical schools and elect medicine for a life-time profession.

    The emphasis in Singapore today on science and technology is necessary and unquestionable at this stage of national development. However, this emphasis has unfortunately taken its toll and amputated, quite inadvertently, one of the limbs of essential services, i.e, the medical and associated services. Singapore today has a doctor population of approximately 1,500 registered practitioners. This gives a doctor population ratio of 1:1,300 or 1:1,400. Many Western countries have attained the figure of 1:500, and they still continue to face a shortage of doctors and its related problems. If I were to proceed in my analysis and take the figure of 1:750 as a desirable ratio to work on - I have chosen this figure in view of the enhanced living standards and sophistication and, again, the rising expectations of the people -- we are today short of at least 1,000 doctors.

2.45 p.m.

    Allowing for this shortage, and the exercise of natural deaths and unnatural accidents, we need at least between 100 and 120 new doctors annually to join the ranks of the medical profession. Do we have these many doctors graduating every year? As it is, Government medical institutions are understaffed. What with projected plans for setting up new hospitals? I have chosen this sitting of Parliament to highlight this serious and, I think, potentially catastrophic problem. Sir, if I may submit figures to illustrate my point.

    In the medical school today, from Year 5 to Year 1, the number of medical students divided into citizens and non-citizens are as follows: 

                  Singapore     Non-

                   citizens   citizens

     Year 5           87         30

     Year 4           69         27

     Year 3           54         55

     Year 2           54         58

     Year 1           38         87

You will notice that for the non-citizens, the ratio is completely reversed. To analyse this figure, let us take the final and first-year students ratio. Final year, 30 non-citizens, 87 Singaporeans. First year, exactly the reverse, 87 non-citizens and 38 Singaporeans.

    In the Dental Faculty, a greater disparity is shown: 

                  Singapore     Non-

                   citizens   citizens

Final year            14         20

Third year             3         35

Second year            3         32

First year             8         37

For the School of Pharmacy, the figures are: 

                  Singapore     Non-

                   citizens   citizens

Final year            10         10

Second year            6         17

First year             7         19


    Therefore, Sir, in the medical school, the number of Singapore students has dropped from 74 per cent to a low of 30 per cent. In the Dental Faculty, only 28 out of 152 students are Singapore citizens. In the School of Pharmacy, only 23 out of 69, that is 1:3, are citizens.

Column: 940

We need dental surgeons very badly. We need pharmacists very badly, and we are also short of doctors. The various professional bodies can, I am sure, provide more detailed analyses if the figures I have just given are not sufficient to wake the authorities concerned. To my mind, there are four approaches to solve the problem.

    (1) The Ministry of Education, in streaming students in the late secondary and pre-university classes, must advise students or allow them to choose subjects that will give them greater flexibility. There should be room for them to choose in gaining admissions to the university between Science, Engineering, or Medical and associated schools.

    (2) A question of motivation. Parents and students must be made fully aware of good job prospects and also of the present manpower shortage problem in the Health Ministry, in the hospitals and related professions.

    (3) A greater incentive must be provided in terms of salary and service conditions. Of course, pride and interest in the profession, dedication and mobility of the career must also be major considerations in electing careers for our school children.

    (4) The question of recruitment of non-citizens into our medical institutions. Over the past few years an increasing number of non-citizens have been recruited into our expanding medical service. The non-citizens in this year's medical graduating class have all been issued with forms asking them to apply houseman's jobs in Singapore. With the figures I have given, I guess we shall have to do the same next year, the year following and the year following. However, past experience has shown that many, if not most, of these new doctors have taken up appointment as housemen only to get themselves fully registered in Singapore. And then, using Singapore as a stepping stone, they leave for Australia, the United States, or England, or back to where they have come from. I must admit that some stayed behind, but the number is small. Further, we have recruited an increasing number of specialists from the Indian

Column: 941

sub-continent states to help us run our existing service. I do not wish at this stage to enter into a discussion as to the merits or demerits of recruiting foreigners into our essential services. Unless steps are taken to get our own citizens to run the store, I can well imagine that with time

    The Chairman: Order. Dr Ong, you have already spoken for ten minutes. May I remind hon. Members that the guillotine time for this Head is 3.00 p.m. Mr Chua.

    The Minister for Health and Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, if I may first answer the last speaker, i.e, the Member for Kim Seng. I have very little to quarrel with what he has just said. With regard to shortage of doctors, if he had, in fact, followed some of my speeches made as far back as 18 months ago, he would have heard me say that because of our expanding programme of development for the medical specialities and so on, we would be short of doctors.

    As regards recruitment of - doctors, since we are short of doctors, we cannot he very discriminating as to whether they are citizens or non-citizens. If we have our own citizens among them, they will be given first choice. If we have not got applications from our citizens, we recruit non-citizens.

    The other point is about the intake of students in the medical school. We have done our very best to encourage students to go into the medical school and, after graduation, to come into our service. One of the steps which the Ministry of Health has done was to have a traineeship scheme whereby ordinary doctors can at the shortest possible time qualify themselves to become specialists. That, in itself, has been quite a great attraction to many medical officers.

    On the point of conditions of service and pay of ordinary doctors and nurses, may I say that, as far as nurses are concerned, a decision was recently handed down by the Industrial Arbitration

Column: 942

Court. In fact, the Court made awards to raise the salaries of nurses quite substantially and it even elevated the divisional status of nurses. Therefore, I would say that the terms and conditions of service and pay of the nurses are now on par with the other services which have got salary revisions. The' other point about ordinary doctors is a matter which, I think, the Minister for Finance did indicate that as far as the lower echelon of the civil service is concerned, a revision of their salaries will take place. That is a matter which squarely rests with the Minister for Finance.

    The point raised by the Member for Toa Payoh concerns mental cases which have been discharged from Woodbridge Hospital. I fully sympathise with the plight of some of the families who have to take back their relatives who have been discharged from the Woodbridge Hospital. May I say this: the modern trend in psychiatric care is to admit mentally-ill patients into a psychiatric hospital only if they require active psychiatric treatment. As far as possible, patients should be treated as outpatients so that they will not lose their connection with their families and the community. This method of treatment is not only economical but it also prevents the patient from deteriorating as a result of prolonged stay in an institution. Outpatient management does in certain instances result in a social problem to families and neighbours, especially if they stay in a Housing Board flat, as stated by the Member for Toa Payoh. The solution is to develop psychiatric day-centres, and it is intended to include this in the future development of the Outram Road General Hospital. Such day-centres sometimes referred to as day hospitals are, in fact, identical to the creche that we see in our community. In the meantime, a half-way home i being set up in Sembawang - perhaps the Member for Sembawang will take note of this - for mental patients who are about to be discharged from Woodbridge Hospital. This half-way home is to rehabilitate them and to readjust them back to normal life with

Column: 943

their families, so that they will not be a problem to their families when they eventually return home.

    The Member for Anson mentioned the case of a patient who went to Thomson Road General Hospital but could not get himself treated for a compound fracture. May I correct the misapprehension of the Member for Anson? He thinks that all hospitals can deal with complicated cases. In fact, if you have a compound fracture, it is an orthopaedic case. It is a case for the specialist. As far as Thomson Road General Hospital is concerned, it is not as big a hospital as Outram Road General Hospital. It has less than 400 beds, and it is therefore not possible to provide every speciality in that particular hospital. Orthopaedic surgery is one speciality which cannot be provided in the Thomson Road General Hospital. Therefore, if there is a case of complicated fracture, it has to be referred to the Orthopaedic Unit of the Outram Road General Hospital.

    The case in question, which the Member for Anson brought up, is this: when the patient came up to the Thomson Road General Hospital, the surgeon there wanted to deal with the case on an emergency basis. At the same time the surgeon did explain to the patient that it would be better if he were treated in the Orthopaedic Unit of the Outram Road General Hospital. The father of the patient concerned was quite happy to go to the Outram Road General Hospital, instead of being treated first on a preliminary basis in the Thomson Road General Hospital. Of course, in that event he had to wait because the orthopaedic surgeon had to be contacted. In fact, the orthopaedic surgeon was eventually contacted, and the patient was sent to the Outram. Road General Hospital.

    Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon (Tiong Bahru)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to take this opportunity, on behalf of my constituents, to make a request to the authorities in charge of the Outram Road General Hospital. This request comes from people who live in Hospital quarters. They are Grade III Medical and Health servants living in the quarters at Outram Road. These low-salaried staff occupy quarters at a low rent, which is a very reasonable move of the Government. But the problem is that these quarters are too old, and the facilities are too basic and inadequate. Those who live there have to share a communal kitchen, a communal toilet and also a communal bathroom for their showers. There are many other inconveniences in these quarters. Very often they quarrel among themselves over the use of these communal facilities.

    Another problem is that if one occupant unfortunately passes away, or

Column: 945

is dismissed from the service for one reason or another, or retires when he reaches the age, then his family cannot continue to occupy the quarters. Mr Speaker, Sir, we all know that in Singapore today it is not easy to look for alternative housing. If a person applies for a Housing Board flat, he will have to wait for a few years before he gets his chance. But we know that the Housing and Development Board does give priority to certain applicants under special circumstances. In any case, at very short notice, it is not easy to look for a place to live in.

    Accommodation is one of the most important things in life. Under the present circumstances, therefore, these people whom I have mentioned have this request to make. They would like to ask the authorities concerned to make arrangements with the Housing Board so that they can move into Housing Board flats. From my investigations, among these people who live in these quarters, the majority of them have already applied either to buy or to rent Housing Board flats. But the Housing Board will not give priority to them. So they are requesting the authorities concerned to liaise with the Housing Board in order that priority can be given to their applications for flats, so that the Government could demolish the old quarters and use the land for some other purposes.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, these quarters, which the Member for Tiong Bahru referred to, were built by the former Singapore Improvement Trust for the Outram Road General Hospital. Consideration will therefore be given to the construction of new quarters in the re-development of the Outram Road General Hospital.

duty and responsibility to maintain law and order in our society. In recent years, the Police have improved their efficiency and relationship with the people. This is something which deserves our praise.

    However, I have a few questions to raise here. In recent years the corrosive influence of Western countries, particularly the hippy sub-culture from abroad, has caused certain undesirable effects on our youths. One of the bad influences is that our young people are now sporting long hair as a fashion. They would grow their hair down to their shoulders. Some of them sport a rather long beard, even though they are very young. They adorn themselves with all kinds of fancy clothes. Their behaviour really poses a social problem. The craze for long hair has become more prevalent in our society. It is now one of the many social problems Government has to face. It is also one of the problems which parents have to face.
